summary: This is a defense expert disclosure filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team in her criminal case. It outlines the expected testimony of two defense experts, Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Park Dietz, who will challenge the reliability of witness memories and the prosecution's theory of 'grooming'. This document is a defense filing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, providing notice of expert witnesses the defense intends to call. It includes extensive discussion of psychological pathways to false allegations of sexual assault, citing research, and lists several experts in psychiatry, law, computer forensics, financial investigation, and document examination.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of recruiting and grooming minors for Jeffrey Epstein. Her defense team is submitting this expert disclosure.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: A psychologist and memory expert disclosed by the defense. She is expected to testify about the fallibility of memory, including how false memories can be created through suggestion.

persons.name: Park Dietz
persons.context: A forensic psychiatrist disclosed by the defense. He is expected to critique the prosecution's expert on 'grooming', discuss cognitive biases like hindsight bias and the halo effect, and outline pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as the primary beneficiary of the alleged grooming-by-proxy. Described as a brilliant but flawed man with Cluster B personality traits who manipulated people.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: The prosecution's expert witness whose opinions on 'grooming' and victim vulnerabilities are directly criticized and rebutted by Dr. Park Dietz in this disclosure.

persons.name: Steve Bannon
persons.context: Mentioned as having conducted a videotaped interview with Jeffrey Epstein where Epstein discussed different kinds of power.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Cited by Dr. Dietz as an example of a person with 'political power' whom Jeffrey Epstein was said to gravitate towards, illustrating the 'halo effect'.

persons.name: Gerry Edelman
persons.context: Cited by Dr. Dietz as an example of a person with 'intellectual power' whom Jeffrey Epstein was said to gravitate towards, illustrating the 'halo effect'.

persons.name: Emily R. Dworkin
persons.context: Cited as an author of meta-analyses on mental disorders associated with sexual assault and PTSD following sexual assault.

persons.name: Ryan Hall
persons.context: Performed an independent medical and psychiatric evaluation of an unnamed individual in 2009. Defense expert who will offer opinions and diagnoses.

persons.name: Bennett Gershman
persons.context: Distinguished Professor of Law at Pace University, expert on prosecutorial misconduct. Expected to testify on best practices to ensure prosecution integrity.

persons.name: Robert Kelso
persons.context: CEO of Forensic Pursuit, expert in computer forensics. Will testify about user data from seized devices and may rebut testimony from the government's expert Stephen Halley.

persons.name: John Lopez
persons.context: Former IRS Special Agent, financial investigator. Will testify about his review of financial records and fund transfers provided in discovery.

persons.name: Gerald LaPorte
persons.role: Forensic Chemist and Document Dating Specialist
persons.context: Director of Research Innovation for Florida International University. Will analyze documents for date of creation, completeness, alteration, and manipulation.

persons.name: Jennifer Naso
persons.context: Former U.S. Secret Service Document Analyst. Will examine documents for authorship and authentication.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney who signed and filed this defense notice of expert witnesses.

persons.name: Stephen Halley
persons.context: Mentioned as a government expert whose testimony Robert Kelso may rebut.

persons.name: Caron Zlotnick
persons.context: Cited as an author of research on chronicity in PTSD and predictors of its course.

persons.name: Meredith Warshaw
persons.context: Co-author with Caron Zlotnick on research about chronic PTSD.

persons.name: Anna E. Jaffe
persons.context: Co-author with Emily Dworkin on research about PTSD following sexual assault.

persons.name: Michele Bedard-Gilligan
persons.context: Co-author with Emily Dworkin on research about PTSD following sexual assault.

persons.name: Skye Fitzpatrick
persons.context: Co-author with Emily Dworkin on research about PTSD following sexual assault.

connections.description: Maxwell is accused of recruiting and grooming minors to provide sexualized massages for Epstein, characterized by the defense as an alleged 'grooming-by-proxy' relationship.
Dr. Loftus is a defense expert witness retained by Maxwell's legal team to testify on memory issues.
Dr. Dietz is a defense expert witness retained by Maxwell's legal team to testify on psychiatry and critique the prosecution's theories.
Epstein is described as gravitating towards people with power, such as Bill Clinton's political power.
Epstein gave a videotaped interview to Steve Bannon where he discussed power.
Dr. Dietz's testimony is designed to directly rebut and criticize the opinions of the prosecution's expert, Dr. Rocchio, particularly on 'grooming'.
Kelso, a defense computer forensics expert, may offer rebuttal testimony to testimony offered by the government's expert, Stephen Halley.
Pagliuca is the defense attorney who filed this expert notice on behalf of defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Dr. Hall is a defense expert who evaluated an individual and will offer opinions relevant to the defense of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Defense Expert Disclosure Filing
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files a formal disclosure outlining the expected testimony of their expert witnesses, Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Park Dietz.

events.title: Psychiatric Evaluation by Dr. Hall
events.description: Dr. Ryan Hall performed an independent medical and psychiatric evaluation of an unnamed individual.

keyFacts: The defense plans to call memory expert Dr. Elizabeth Loftus to testify that false memories can be created through suggestion, media coverage, and conversations, and can be described with confidence and emotion.

The defense plans to call forensic psychiatrist Dr. Park Dietz to challenge the prosecution's theory of 'grooming', arguing the term imputes motive without evidence and that a theory of 'grooming-by-proxy' has no scientific support.

Dr. Dietz will testify about cognitive biases relevant to the case, including 'hindsight bias' (judging past events as more predictable after knowing the outcome) and the 'halo effect' (where positive traits like wealth or status influence other judgments).
Dr. Dietz cites a videotaped interview where Jeffrey Epstein told Steve Bannon that he 'gravitated to people of power,' such as Bill Clinton's political power or Gerry Edelman's intellectual power.

Dr. Dietz outlines 11 potential 'pathways to false allegations of sexual assault,' including lying, false memories, intoxication, and various personality disorders, drawing from a peer-reviewed article.

The defense outlines multiple psychological pathways they argue can lead to false allegations of sexual assault, including false memory, intoxication, and various personality disorders (antisocial, borderline, histrionic).
The defense cites academic research to argue that emotional distress (e.g., crying) is not a reliable predictor of the truthfulness of a sexual assault allegation.

The defense provides notice of several expert witnesses they intend to call, including a forensic psychiatrist (Ryan Hall), a prosecutorial misconduct expert (Bennett Gershman), and specialists in computer forensics, financial investigation, and document examination.
A key point from Dr. Hall's evaluation is that the evaluated individual 'did not identify Ms. Maxwell as a perpetrator of any abuse.'
The document is a strategic defense filing aiming to cast doubt on accusers' credibility and challenge the prosecution's evidence through expert testimony.
